folder: Broome Street & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Holland Tunnel Entrance (580) and 578 to 570 Broome Street, north side, between Hudson and Varick Streets. The tunnel has not quite yet been opened to the public. No 570 is the Roman Catholic Church of our Lady of Vilna. No 574 is the Duane Methodist Episcopal Church, which settled down at this address late in 1929. The old church (about 1862), at 292 Hudson Street, on the east side, south of Spring Street was demolished in 1923 (see Hudson Street). Originally the church was on Duane Street, where it was established in 1797 and stood till destroyed by fire in 1861.
September 27, 1927

folder: Broome Street & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Holland Tunnel Plaza and Broome Street, north side, from No. 582 Broome, east of Hudson, to Clark Street (Sixth Avenue Extension).
October 11,1928.
P. L. Sperr.

folder: Broome Street & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Entrance to the Holland Vehicular Tunnel, site of 578-582 Broome Street,north side, east of Hudson Street, showing four policemen and a toll collector keeping order as pleasure cars take the plunge into the tile lined tunnel, nearly a mile long. The office at the right is trying to look severe and dignified, much to the amusement of the one in the right rear of the group.
Summer 1928

folder: Hudson Street & Broome Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Hudson Street, east side, from Broome Street to Vestry, showing the new Holland Plaza Building in the block bounded by Watts,
Hudson, Canal and Varick Streets.
November 6, 1929.
Brown Brothers.

folder: Hudson Street & Broome Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Hudson Street, west side, from Broome Street to Vandam, from and including the east side from Watts Street to Dominick. The east side of Hudson Street, from Broome to Dominick, has been
demolished to make a site for a new building.
February 12, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
#261-3 Hudson Street,West side between Spring and Watts Street
looking Northwards.
October 2nd,1938.
P.L.Sperr,
No reproductions.
(3)Hudson Street, West side and Broome Street at the end of the
latter Street.
October 2nd,1938.
P.L.Sperr,
No Reproductions.

text:

clearance from Renwick Street.
